channel.title: NYT > U.S.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: In College and Hiding From Scary Ideas
item.description: Universities, rather than being forums for free expression, are encouraging “safe spaces” to protect delicate sensibilities.
item.dc:creator: JUDITH SHULEVITZ

item.title: Princeton 80, Wisconsin Green-Bay 70: Princeton Remains Unbeaten as Obama Watches
item.description: With a victory over Wisconsin Green-Bay, undefeated Princeton joined Harvard in 1998 as the only Ivy League women’s programs to win a game in the N.C.A.A. tournament.
item.dc:creator: ZACH SCHONBRUN
item.media:description: Green Bay's Megan Lukan, center, is pressured by Princeton's Alex Wheatley, left, and Blake Dietrick.

item.title: From Minneapolis to ISIS: An American’s Path to Jihad
item.description: The chilling progression of a Minnesota man suggests that the Islamic State may rely on recruiters inside the United States and shows how hard it is to predict who will be swept away by ideological fervor.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: Abdi Nur, right, posted a photo online from Syria. A friend, Abdullahi Yusuf, left, was stopped as he tried to depart. Top, an image of Western passports put up by a Twitter user who says she is an American with the Islamic State.

item.title: Izola Ware Curry, Who Stabbed King in 1958, Dies at 98
item.description: In 1958, Ms. Curry stabbed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at a Harlem book signing — an episode that a decade later would become a rhetorical touchstone in the last oration of his life.
item.category: National Assn for the Advancement of Colored People
item.dc:creator: MARGALIT FOX

item.title: Panic at New Orleans Airport as Police Shoot Man Who Attacked T.S.A. Officers
item.description: A man attacked security officers at New Orleans airport with wasp spray and a machete before being shot by a sheriff’s deputy stationed at the airport, officials said.
item.dc:creator: CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and LIAM STACK

item.title: From Minneapolis to ISIS: An American’s Path to Jihad
item.description: The chilling progression of a Minnesota man suggests that the Islamic State may rely on recruiters inside the United States and shows how hard it is to predict who will be swept away by ideological fervor.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: Abdi Nur, right, posted a photo online from Syria. A friend, Abdullahi Yusuf, left, was stopped as he tried to depart. Top, an image of Western passports put up by a Twitter user who says she is an American with the Islamic State.

item.title: First Draft: House Benghazi Committee Requests Hillary Clinton Email Server
item.description: The committee investigating the Benghazi attacks formally asked Mrs. Clinton to turn over the server that housed the personal account she used as secretary of state.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: Hillary Rodham Clinton testified about Benghazi in 2013. The committee investigating the Benghazi attacks formally requested on Friday that she turn over her email server

item.title: Wisconsin: Judge Strikes Abortion Law
item.description: A federal judge on Friday struck down a Wisconsin law requiring doctors performing abortions to get hospital admitting privileges.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Obama Calls Nominee ‘Hostage’ of Trafficking Dispute
item.description: President Obama on Friday said that Republicans were holding Loretta E. Lynch “hostage” to a legislative disagreement unrelated to her nomination as attorney general.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: See No Junk Food, Buy No Junk Food
item.description: Stores that accept food stamps should give more space to produce.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS A. FARLEY and RUSSELL SYKES

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: How to Make Landslides Less Deadly
item.description: We need to identify these hazards to mitigate the threat.
item.dc:creator: DAVID R. MONTGOMERY and JOSEPH WARTMAN

item.title: Philadelphia Commissioner Steps Into Fray Between Police and Public
item.description: Even in a city with a black chief of police, relations between law enforcement and the public are strained.
item.dc:creator: TIMOTHY WILLIAMS
item.media:credit: Steven M. Falk/Philadelphia Inquirer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Protesters threw chairs during a town hall meeting in Philadelphia that was attended by Charles Ramsey, the police commissioner.

item.title: Officials Urge Patience as Hanging of Black Man Is Investigated in Mississippi
item.description: Two federal law enforcement officials suggested that the hanging of Otis James Byrd might have been a suicide, but other officials said it was too early draw conclusions.
item.dc:creator: CAMPBELL ROBERTSON and RICHARD FAUSSET
item.media:credit: Josh Edwards/The Vicksburg Post, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Claiborne County officials prepared to leave a home in Port Gibson, Miss., on Thursday as they investigated a hanging.

item.title: U.S. May Stay in Afghanistan After '16
item.description: President Obama is considering leaving American troops in Afghanistan after he leaves office, instead of only a small force to protect the embassy in Kabul, a White House official said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: White House Antagonism Toward Netanyahu Grows
item.description: Despite Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s election victory, he is still out of the good graces of the Obama administration, which has had to reassess its policy toward Israel.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: $20 Million Settlement in False Conviction
item.description: A man who was freed from prison after 20 years for a murder he did not commit was awarded $20 million in a settlement that his lawyers said is the highest individual settlement ever in a wrongful conviction case.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Arkansas: Bill Would Prohibit Giving Away Children
item.description: A lawmaker who gave away his adopted daughters to a man who later sexually assaulted one of them voted Friday to make such transfers a felony punishable by up to five years in prison.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Washington: Suit Over Oil Drilling Fleet Advances
item.description: A state judge said Friday that a lawsuit challenging the Port of Seattle’s decision to lease one of its terminals as a home port for an Arctic oil drilling fleet can go forward.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Carolina: Alcohol Banned at Fraternity Events
item.description: North Carolina State University said Friday that it was temporarily banning alcohol at social events for most fraternities after two chapters were suspended, one of them amid drug and sexual assault allegations.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Florida Justices Reject 70-Year Sentence for Juvenile, Likening It to Life Term
item.description: The Florida Supreme Court ordered a new hearing for Shimeek D. Gridine, who was 14 when he wounded a man with a shotgun during an attempted robbery.
item.dc:creator: ERIK ECKHOLM
